Fields.DialogueText: Surcouf, are you ready? We're coming up on some Morganas.
Un moment, Capitaine!
And... there we go! Bon appetit, mes amours!
Who were you talking to, anyway?
I was feeding the pufferfish, naturellement!
Where are we keeping pufferfish?
In the secret aquarium.
Why?
They're a Japanese delicacy! Poisonous if prepared wrong, you know.
We're smuggling seafood?
I prefer to think of it as sharing my love of this most dangerous dish with the world!
That still doesn't explain why we have an aquarium.
For the same reason we have a wine vault.
Which is...?
Why would I do anything if it did not entertain me?

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes I think I'll never understand you.
To save the world?
I'll have to have a closer look at your requisitions. Fish food isn't exactly essential.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien. I am not meant to be understood.
Peut-être. I keep all my things there!
S'il vous plaît faire! I was starting to wonder whether you'd ever even read them. The things one can get away with...
That's quite an attitude for a Belle to have.
Merci, Capitaine! You are always so kind.
I didn't mean it as—
Tais-toi! The Morganas will hear.
@BATTLE
Surcouf! There you are. I've been looking everywhere for you.
Il y a le problème, Capitaine! Even I cannot be everywhere. You'd best narrow your search next time.

Fields.MenuText: I... what? You're not making sense.
Quit throwing up smokescreens. You need to explain these requisitions.
It's difficult to search for someone who doesn't want to be found.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps you are asking the wrong questions?
Avec plaisir! You know I value nothing more than transparency.
That is the point of being hidden, non?
Don't get cute with me—
A reflex, Capitaine, and I invite you to enjoy it.
As I was saying—
What was that? We've Morganas coming into range? We'd best dive, hadn't we?
... Fine. I wanted to talk about your supply requisitions, but we'll discuss this later. Work on your timing, won't you?
I rather think I have mastered it.
@BATTLE
You're looking lively. That ought to give today's Morgana something to think about.
One cannot afford not to be lively, Capitaine! Not against a tireless enemy.
That reminds me—you're still on the hook for those requisitions.
Oui, oui, oui. We'll deal with it over dinner or something. Move to flank?
If you would.
@BATTLE
Well, there they go! And here I go. I really must get back to my—
After we've discussed your requisitions.
Oui. We resupply at the end of the week, non?
Yes, but—
And the deadline for submitting them to Command was when?
... Yesterday.
Then why discuss my shopping list? Ce qui est fait est fait.

Fields.MenuText: You may be a Belle, but that doesn't mean you can live in such blatant luxury.
Surcouf, your personal effects are worth over half the crew's rations combined.
This isn't a shopping list, it's a treasure hoard.

Fields.DialogueText: I am used to a certain lifestyle, Capitaine! Surely you understand.
Que puis-je dire? Command loves us. Lay that at their feet, not mine.
And I the sleeping dragon!
Just look at this. You buy cigarettes by the crate?
Je sui un sous-marin, Capitaine. My lungs are stronger than the average sailor's. Perhaps from holding my breath underwater!
Ha ha. And you've got dozens of pounds of coffee here. Who drinks that much coffee?
Moi.
All right, bad question. Why?
Keep hours like mine and perhaps you will understand. Being busy is a virtue!
This is insane. We're at war. I can't go to Command and ask them to restock your wine vault.
But you already have, Capitaine. Check the requisition records.
All conveniently submitted after it's too late to make changes, I imagine.
Now you are catching on!
Capitaine? Capitaine! Réveillez-vous!
What? What is it?
Rien d'important, but I thought you deserved to know. The world does not wait for sleepers!
This better be good.
Bien sûr! Command has recently informed us that we're to make for Bermuda.
Why is it that you know this and I don't?
Because I read the communiqué.
I'm the captain here.
I was awake.
You're always awake.
Vrai! I recommend it. I also recommend evasive maneuvers against the nearby Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: You and I are going to have a long talk about your priorities once this is over.
Why didn't you say so? I should be on the bridge right now!
If one of my crew reported an enemy's presence that way, they'd be mopping decks for the rest of his tour.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, allons-nous? I do so love our talks! It's like watching a puppy bark at its reflection.
Tu me dîs! A capitaine should really be more on top of things.
Ha! "Your crew."
@BATTLE
The Morganas are retreating. Shall we pursue?
Proceed.
@BATTLE
Shall we congratulate each other on today's victory?
Later. I'm sure you know why I've dragged you into my office.
For the sheer ecstasy of my company, si je devais deviner.
To be frank, you're going a little mad with power.
Je ne suis pas d'accord. Power is a muscle. It must be flexed lest it atrophy!
Is that how you explain using the men for personal errands?
You know what they say about idle hands, Capitaine. And tied to the ship as I am, there are some things I cannot do alone.
Our helmsman was caught smuggling opium! I had to collect him from military police after shore leave in Algiers!
Oh, pas de mal. I bribed them too!
You're living like a queen in the middle of a war zone. How do you explain that?
Que puis-je dire? I'm good with money. And a queen is entitled to a comfy throne.

Fields.MenuText: See, that right there is exactly the sort of behavior I won't tolerate.
There's being good with money and then there's running a criminal empire.
And obedient subjects, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: When have I ever worried about what you tolerate?
I call that being very good with money!
Ne voyez-vous pas? You know your place already!
Enough jokes. I'm of a mind to report everything to Command and let them deal with you.
"Oh, don't worry, Surcouf. Just sail about like a good girl and maybe you'll be retired with honors and scrapped!"
First of all, that is not what I sound like. Second—
While we're on the subject of things that sound like you, need I remind you of the Morgana manifests? The ones with your signature and authorization?
You're playing a dangerous game, Surcouf.
Bien. I wield too much power. Curtail it.
The air's certainly grown... ominous, non?
You can thank the Morganas for that. Our route to Bermuda takes us within miles of the Atlantic maelstrom.
The Royal Navy likes to live dangerously! Such daring. I would call it foolish if I weren't so curious.

Fields.MenuText: You live for this sort of thing, don't you?
Curious to know how the crew would handle the terror, you mean?
You're not still on about the Morgana salvage, are you?

Fields.DialogueText: I may even die for it, Capitaine. But I will make sure I am the last to do so.
Oh, don't be so boring. That must have crossed your mind at least once!
Non, Capitaine, I am not. The financial potential is simply not worth the risk in these waters, and that is saying something.
Well, it's going to be dangerous no matter how you look at it. The Royal Navy Dockyard wants requisitions in a week in advance for all supply stops. In and out.
Oui, oui. I've heard the reefs are a terror!
Enough of one that they'll only service our ships one at a time. All eyes are on you, Surcouf.
Charmant. Hiding in plain sight—the thought thrills me!
Whatever floats your... well, never mind. Didn't you have a letter to the mafia or something to write?
To the Camorra. The mafia were yesterday! Expect my requisition at the usual time, of course.
Late?
Precisely when I mean it! ... But a Morgana approaches. Action stations, then! I leave you to your captaining afterwards.
Oh, I'll captain, all right.
@BATTLE
Well, look who's decided to show up.
S'il vous plaît, hold your applause! You'll notice I've altered my usual request, légèrement...
That'll have to wait, Surcouf. Seems your spotter plane's radioing about a Morgana patrol.
Un digne défi! At long last! Besson has such keen eyes.
You're late as usual with your requisition. I doubt a few more hours will kill us.
I knew you'd come around!
@BATTLE
Trop facile. Give me more!
The mid-Atlantic's dangerous these days. I guarantee you'll see plenty like them.
Je ne peux pas attendre! Now, speaking of more...
Yes. I was looking forward to discussing your requisitions.
As was I! Now, I've found myself smoking a little less, so I'm willing to knock off a crate or two...
Let me stop you right there. No coffee and cigarettes.
Excusez-moi?
You heard me.
Ah, Capitaine, you have a black sense of humor. I believe you are simply here to rubber-stamp my orders.
And I believe that the Royal Navy Dockyard doesn't need them early, after all.
Que... Que voulez-vous dire? That communiqué I intercepted—
—Was in response to one I sent myself.
Then the radioman I spoke to—
Took a well-deserved break just the other day.

Fields.MenuText: Speechless at last. I'm impressed.
All I wanted was a chance to talk it over. We'll put this to bed and move on.
I'm willing to let some of this stay... provided that you share.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you must take your victories where you can get them.
I decide who and what is put to bed, Capitaine. And how they are put there.
You drive a cruel bargain, Capitaine.
... Fine. Leave the coffee and I shall allow you three bottles of the Madeira wine I'm after.
A case.
Vous êtes le diable.
I'm flattered. Now, about the cigarettes...
Ah, Bermuda! What's not to love? Clear skies, clear water, clear air...
Clear betrayal?
Are you still pouting?
Non, Capitaine, I am merely pensive. That was quite the deception you pulled off.

Fields.MenuText: It was worth it just to wipe that smirk off your face.
What deception? It's my job as captain to run a clean ship.
It ought to put your tastes into perspective. You can live without the occasional luxury.

Fields.DialogueText: I was not aware you were so interested in mon visage, Capitaine!
You should know by now that I clean up after myself.
Je le savais, but I do not have to.
Is that all, then?
Why, whatever do you mean?
You're taking this rather well.
One does not become reine des corsaires without bruising here and there. Even the great Robert Surcouf was cheated out of treasures from time to time.
Cheated? If anything, I kept you from cheating me.
You misunderstand, Capitaine. I intended it as a compliment.
You've got an interesting way of complimenting people.
Interesting is what I aim for. You have become interesting.
Thanks... I think. Aim for the nearest Morgana, won't you?
Avec plaisir!
@BATTLE
Surcouf, will you come look at this?
À votre service! Dear me... what have we here?
I was given this at the dockyard. I recognize the letterhead. It's from Command. But I can't read it.
Now, really, Capitaine. What are they teaching in capitaine school when you can't read a simple communiqué?
It's in Mongolian!
Now that is odd. Mongolia doesn't even have a navy, do they? I wonder where they found a translator on such short notice.
Never mind that! We need to radio Bermuda right away and get to the bottom of this.
Indeed. Such a shame it would be if only one of us were able to read it...
Why are you smiling?
Do I need an excuse?
What did you do?
Little old me? Rien, rien! Nothing you need worry about.

Fields.MenuText: It's my business to worry about things, Surcouf.
You might have to worry about it if we can't carry out our orders.
Don't tell me you can read Mongolian.

Fields.DialogueText: I daresay you have mastered it, Capitaine.
"We?" I was under the impression that you commanded me!
Bien, I will not tell you.
I want an explanation, now!
Qu'y at-il à expliquer? Although... I may have accidentally tripped and requested that Command send their communiqués in Mongolian. For secrecy's sake, you understand.
You crippled our intelligence for some petty revenge?
"Crippled" is such an ugly word. Let us say I... culturally enriched it. Don't fret, I can read it.
When the hell did you have the time to learn Mongolian? And why?
What better use of one's free time than learning a new language? You never know when it might come in handy!
What does it say?
I am still a novice, but at a guess..."Give me back my cigarettes?" Keep in mind, the subject and object clauses aren't always in the same place—
Damn it! We have Morganas headed this direction... Fine, whatever you want. Put that down and follow me to the bridge.
Tiim ee, minii akhmad!
@BATTLE
And no Mongolian.
Finally. It took them long enough.
Is that the latest communiqué? How mundanely English, Capitaine...
And not Mongolian, thank goodness. If being able to read our orders is mundane, I'll deal with being mundane.
You seem determined to master it.

Fields.MenuText: As far as I'm concerned, the less interesting a war is, the better for everyone.
Better an honest day's work than... whatever it is you do.
Fighting for the fate of the world isn't your idea of interesting?

Fields.DialogueText: Except for those of us who do the interesting things!
If consorting with the underground brings me closer to freedom, then so be it!
Oh, the world will be fine. You humans? I am not so sure.
Would it kill you to pretend to care about your job for a minute?
In the same way that birds must care about flying, I suppose not.
Most birds I know don't blindfold themselves as a joke on their captains.
There was no blindfold—I told you I could read Mongolian, after all! I always know what is going on.
It doesn't bother you that I don't?
Until you take a more active role in your captaincy, I think I can manage on my own.
Bold words for someone who can't function without a crew.
I have no need for boldness, Capitaine. The crew know better already.
I'll be  the judge of that. All ahead full—we're catching that Morgana before it gets any closer to the island.
Now there's someone who functions on her own...
Watch it.
@BATTLE
Surcouf, take a look at this map.
Oui, Capitaine? Qu'en est-il?
This is what Command has planned for us through the foreseeable future, barring emergencies.
Tahiti? My, aren't we well-traveled?
You don't seem excited.
I am the daughter of Robert Surcouf, the terror of l'océan Indien! Give me spices, gold, tropical wood... what does Tahiti have for me? Breadfruit?
Someone's got to help protect Indochina. There's more at stake than your money, you know.
Other people's money?
Never mind.
Non, Capitaine, I am serious! What am I to do stuck in the middle of the south Pacific? Let my contacts wither on the vine like neglected grapes?

Fields.MenuText: Your contacts are well-established criminal organizations. They can get by without you for a few weeks.
This could be your chance to clean up your act.
Start learning Tahitian? I hear pearl farming is big there.

Fields.DialogueText: The whole point of maintaining criminal contacts is to convince them you are indispensable! It's like I've taught you nothing.
Impensable! Where would I get my contraband, then?
Not big enough. And I already have Mongolian to keep you in the dark, minii geriin tejeemel.
Well, there's little we can do about it at this stage. You can strike up a relationship with the yakuza or something.
An excellent idea, Capitaine! I'll steal some of the fire control team to translate.
Wait a minute, that wasn't a suggestion!
I consider everything a suggestion! That is why I have an empire, and you do not.
I'm not even going to touch that one. We have Morganas headed this direction. Action stations.
Action stations...?
I'm not calling you "Empress."
@BATTLE
Doing some light reading?
Si je dois. It would pay to know a little more about Tahiti before I go there.
I don't think I've ever seen you read, come to think of it.
That is because I spend most of my time writing. I am a femme de lettres, after all!
That's one way to admit to conspiring with criminals.
Oh, laisse tomber. You're just jealous that I'm making money hand over fist.

Fields.MenuText: What is it this week?
Less "jealous" than "looking around every corner for mafia assassins."
I should at least get a cut for enabling you.

Fields.DialogueText: Rum-running in the Caribbean! Respect the classics, after all...
Don't you worry about that. If anyone kills you, it will be me!
The thought had crossed my mind. It usually disappears by the fifth glass of wine.
I thought you were trying to emancipate yourself, not steal the world.
What is freedom without a decent nest egg?
"Decent?"
Decent. Obscene. Wealth is relative.
What's that you're drinking, by the way?
Coffee?
Well, it's just not your usual mug.
It was the oddest thing, Capitaine. That fleurs-de-lis mug I love went missing this morning.
Did it now?
Oui. I finally found it in the galley, though—one of the men was drinking tea out of It. Tea, out of my coffee mug. Just imagine.
Is that why there was a navigator in the infirmary with a black eye?
The men know I like my things in order. They were briefed on me. They should have been briefed on the hardness of porcelain.
Don't try and pin this on me. I won't have you assaulting my men.
I'll try and save it for the Morganas. Though they at least know not to touch my dishes.
@BATTLE
Ils devraient tous être castrés par des démons!
Calm the hell down! What's going on?
None of your concern! Someone will burn for this!
Not while we're on patrol, they won't! Now tell me what's the matter!
You would not understand!
Try me.
Some fou idiot has desecrated my bed! The red-and-blue sheets are gone! Replaced with paysan, military-issue white!

Fields.MenuText: This is why you've got the whole ship cowering?
Oh, come on. This is just childish.
Surcouf, when was the last time you even slept?

Fields.DialogueText: If the men cower when I am annoyed, they will fall over themselves to serve me when I am truly angered!
What is childish is this flagrant violation of my privacy!
Qu'est-ce que cela fait? It is a matter of principle!
You know, you seem tired. I'm sure if you just slept this off—
Do not mock me, Capitaine! To sleep in that monochrome pit would be the absolute nadir of—
Of?
What is this smile of yours, Capitaine?
I'm not allowed to be happy?
Are you laughing at me? My quarters are defiled and you laugh?
They were just sheets. You'll have them back from laundry in a day.
Blanchisserie peut aller... attends. You had something to do with this, didn't you?
Did I?
It takes a thief to know a thief! The truth is written in the blush at your cheeks, the baring of your teeth in that mockery of a smile!
How did you describe it? "Like watching a puppy bark at its own reflection?"
... I did, didn't I?
Surcouf?
*ALARM*
Non, non. You are right. Tout est juste dans l'amour et la guerre...and there's the alarm.
Truce?
Momentarily. Stand still.
Hey! Not the head!
@BATTLE
What are you doing here?
My ship, my body, my galley, my coffee. What are you doing here?
I couldn't sleep.
I shouldn't sleep.
Some Belles do.
This is true. Certain of my sisters are overly fond of it. But why waste time on something optional?
Like having our communiqués sent to us in Mongolian?
C'est différent. That served a purpose, that purpose being to protect my lifestyle from your meddling.
I don't think I'll ever understand your obsession with luxuries.
At first, I did not either. I am no alcoholic, and cannot be addicted to smoking. The experience is what matters to me, I believe, regardless of the substance.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I follow.
That sounds like something an addict would say.
Is there anything you wouldn't do?

Fields.DialogueText: Je connais, Capitaine. Je connais.
The more languages you speak, the more of the world you understand.
Die.
You humans all eventually die, Capitaine. But it is a different thing to come into this world a weapon.
Purpose-built.
Précisément. I can upgrade, I can refit... But none of it hides the fact that I was made for my era. Born a relic, pourrait-on dire. It is a reminder, in truth.
But then you Belles appeared.
And there we were! No longer merely existing, but... alive. If I want to be reminded of anything, it is that. Aware of my destiny, my experiences, able to shape them with a thought...
So you start a prank war? And raise a fuss over your sheets?
Control, Capitaine. I crave it, most of all when my ambitions are secure and I am bored.
Maybe. Or maybe you're not used to being surprised by your inferiors.
Never mind the short term, Capitaine. I thrive on surprise in the long run... and in that long run, I always get my way.
*ALARM*
Tell the Morganas that.
And in the middle of my coffee. They shall burn!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I have been doing some soul-searching.
You don't say?
Part of me understands your concern regarding your crew. I'll admit, I have sent them into some difficult situations.
Opium smuggling and mafia meetings certainly qualify.
Mais d'autre part, they never would have agreed to any of it—
—If you hadn't blackmailed and extorted each and every one of them?
I did warn them that I was an excellent hand at poker.

Fields.MenuText: Context isn't your strong suit.
Not enough, you didn't.
One more reason not to play with you.

Fields.DialogueText: Au contraire. They are the ones who do not ask the right questions.
Where does my responsibility end and theirs begin? You must hold your men to a higher standard!
We have always played with each other, Capitaine! Why limit our games to the poker table?
Can you get back to the point? We don't have all the time in the world.
Ah, oui! As I was saying, you must understand that I do not believe in guarantees. Except for death and taxes, and there is little that one will not do for their life or their money.
Hence the tricks.
It is simply the way I operate, and I find it gets things done splendidly!
Look, you're not wrong. We've never once been disturbed in port by organized crime, and my men are on their best behavior... even if they're afraid of you.
My results are indéniable!
But you don't have to do everything this way. Some things you can get just by asking.
A novel concept, but I will try to remember it in the future.
Here's an example. After we deal with these Morganas, kindly get the fish out of my quarters before the smell sets in.
And in exchange?
I don't replace your possessions with the generic variety. Sheets or otherwise.
Jamais l'amant.
@BATTLE
Have you moved at all since last night?
Only to bother the radiomen. I do not send all my messages on paper.
Tying up loose ends?
And fraying others. We won't be in Europe for the foreseeable future, so I must table my major dealings with the mafia pour l'instant.
I'm sure the American mafia will pick up the slack.
And the Irish mob when we get to Washington! They gave me a few names back in Europe that I'm sure will lead to amitiés merveilleuses!

Fields.MenuText: I think you and I define friendship differently.
For as long as you're an asset to them.
Where do you find these people?

Fields.DialogueText: "What have you done for me lately?" If you cannot answer that, there is no relationship, working or otherwise!
Ha! To be an asset is to have no ambition. I am a benefactor!
Reputation is currency. Sprinkle some art treasures here, some gold there, and the clients will find you!
If you were human you'd have a bright future in politics.
A boring future, franchement. Everyone would expect my trickery!
As if I don't already. Coffee?
Trop gentil, Capitaine! Though after we deal with these Morganas, non?
@BATTLE
Breathe in that flavor, Capitaine! Is it not smoldering with promise?
It's just coffee.
To one who merely sleepwalks through life, peut-être. For one who values her time as highly as myself, it is life's blood!
Well, you enjoy it. I'll see you later.
Later? Must you leave me alone, Capitaine?
You might say that...
Yawn... Mon Dieu... what time is it?
What time indeed?
... Capitaine? How long was I asleep?
Longer than I've ever seen you sleep. You surprised me.
Qu'est-ce que tu racontes?

Fields.MenuText: Don't be that way, you looked like you needed it.
See? You're looking livelier already!
Don't worry, you didn't miss anything.

Fields.DialogueText: The only thing I need, Capitaine, is your head on a pike!
Tell l'empereur Napoleon just how lively I am when I send you to meet him in Hell!
Est-tu stupide? I have missed everything!
I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about.
Non! I have played this game with you too often to fall for it now! Tell me what you did or I swear on the grave of Robert Surcouf I will keelhaul you!
You'd keelhaul me anyway.
Then do me a favor and give me a thrice-damned excuse!
You read all the communiqués. Did you happen to notice when the engineers requisitioned extra benzene?
Oui, but what does that have to do with—
An active ingredient in decaffeination? You tell me.
... Capitaine, tu n'as pas fait.
Didn't do what?
I would advise you, Capitaine, to thank whatever god you believe in that there are Morganas nearby.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
What was that you fired at the Morgana toward the end? It didn't look like any shell I've ever seen.
My aim was to lay the Morgana to rest. Pensez, Capitaine. What works wonders to put a Belle to sleep?
You fired the last of your coffee at her?
Il était du poison! What else did you expect me to do with it?
You can't still be angry that I decaffeinated some of your coffee.
Try me, Capitaine! You will find... wait. "Some?"
I didn't have enough time to sabotage all of it.
Scélérat!! You will have time enough in your coffin when I am through with you!

Fields.MenuText: You're not going to kill me over a cup of bad coffee.
I can't believe you're this worked up about a prank.
You're just angry that you lost our little war.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr que non, but it will be a factor!
I cannot believe you go to your grave so flippantly!
The war shall end when I say it ends!
Do you remember when I told you how you would die?
When the hell did you say that?
I told you that your signature was all over my Morgana contraband! Enough to have you imprisoned for centuries, if not executed! And still you defy me? Imbécile!
All I did was serve you decaf. You took a nap, Surcouf!
A nap? I have not slept since we met!
What?
Did you think I was kidding all those late nights? All that time I spent writing to thieves the world over? Two days I might have closed countless deals, and now they are gone! Mort!
How would I know?
How? Was it not you who said "some things you can get just by asking?"
Oh, come off it! When do I ever get a straight answer out of you?
My time is more valuable than yours, Capitaine! You will not be obsolete before the century is half over! Your time is not measured in months! You will not wander the seas alone until—
Then do what you usually do! If you're going to get me out of the way, why not wait until it's too late? Why tell me at all?
You dare ask questions of—
That's a little too close.
... Capitaine... you...
I think we're done for today. I'll call you when we're in Washington.
What else do I keep you around for?
You've got your war face on. Someone must have inspired you.
Surcouf, we're entering the Chesapeake Bay.
... Surcouf?
Bonne après-midi.
What have you got there?
Where?
Don't start. Behind your back. And you really shouldn't be smoking in here.
Do not concern yourself. Rien ne vous besoin de voir.
What do you mean, nothing I need to see?
Capitaine, I know there is no reason for us to trust each other. But please, believe me when I say that it is a matter of life and death.

Fields.MenuText: Why should I?
Whose life are we discussing?
I suppose there's nothing I can do about it either way.

Fields.DialogueText: When has that ever mattered?
Mine, always. I suppose that means yours, aussi. It does not matter.
There never is.
Then why even bring it up? Come on, let me see.
Non.
Surcouf, what's on those papers? No, don't you dare—
Stand back!
Good Lord!
You see, Capitaine? Cigarettes are not just for smoking.
You know what? Forget it. Put out the fire in the sink and we'll deal with the Morganas menacing Newport News.
Bien.
@BATTLE
Are you busy?
Toujours, Capitaine.
Good. I wanted to talk.
I never took you for a masochist, Capitaine.
What are you talking about?
How else do our little rendezvous always end, except in you losing something?
What about the pranks?
What about them? I've never fallen for anything in my life.
Look, I wanted to apologize. Obviously I struck a nerve with your coffee, and—
Capitaine, you may stop right there.

Fields.MenuText: Let me finish.
As I was saying—
All right. I know when I'm not wanted.

Fields.DialogueText: But Capitaine, you have said all you needed to say.
Oui, you were. Now let me say something.
You do not. You still have so much to learn.
I appreciate the sentiment, Capitaine. But have you ever once heard me apologize?
No, but I thought—
Non, non, non, non, non. Because I do not regret my actions. The crew, the crime, the cheating... if it all serves a greater purpose, none of it will have been a mistake.
I can't decide if that's the most or the least honorable thing I've ever heard.
Très bien. That is how I know I am doing this correctly.
So you don't want an apology?
Much as I respect it, Capitaine, I respect much more when one sticks to their guns. You had your endgame, and I had mine.
You say that like it's over.
Our little game ended the minute we met, Capitaine. But in whose favor? There is the disagreement.
So no hard feelings about the coffee?
Oh, ne sois pas stupide! If I said I did not want to kill you then, I would be lying. Life is about making sure those murderous urges are simply urges.
So I'm more useful alive?
As long as you believe it, I believe it.
Don't ever change, Surcouf.
Jamais! I will change the world around me... starting with our Morgana friends. Action stations?
Action stations.
@BATTLE
Peace?
Peace.
Enjoying Washington?
What little of it I can see from the deck.
... Right. I'm sorry, I didn't mean-
What did I say about apologizing?
Point. So are you enjoying Washington?
Pure and chaste from afar. It is a good city for curiosity, est-il pas? So many artifacts, so much historical value...
You're thinking about how much you could get for the Declaration of Independence.
You read me like the Declaration itself, Capitaine!
"Pure and chaste", eh?
It's not as if I'm the one in the bars and basements.
I'm surprised the crew has taken to it so well.
You would be surprised at what one can do when one absolutely must.
On pain of death or bankruptcy?
There is that.

Fields.MenuText: Just that?
Fear's a powerful tool.
We all make friends in our own way.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps not just that.
One of many in my bag of tricks, and as easily cured as inflicted!
Friends. Assets. The line begins to blur after so long.
After all, one must throw out a carrot every few lashes of the stick, non?
The pleasure of your company?
More than that, crois le ou pas!
You mean you're not just using the crew as your errand boys?
Not without a sizable severance package at the end of their tour. They would have mutinied otherwise!
You didn't seem worried about that.
Why not, Capitaine? I would have mutinied in their position.
Hmm. So what's your carrot? Freedom?
Hope. Possibility. That's certainly one.
One?
I've been saying it all along, Capitaine. Have you never noticed?
Perhaps not. And I can't notice now. We've got Morganas trying for the bay.
Another time?
Count on it.
@BATTLE
Finalement! Capitaine, a toast!
To what?
We're headed for the Panama Canal, non? From there there is nothing but ocean between us and Tahiti! And you know what that means...

Fields.MenuText: Working on your tan?
No more crime?
Maybe I don't.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr que non! I cultivate a fair complexion!
Well, less of it. That is an unfortunate side effect, je crains.
Someday you will be able to keep up. It is almost endearing!
Non, there is simply less going on between Panama and Tahiti. And that means I may finally relax!
I thought you'd sworn off relaxation.
I take my work seriously, Capitaine, but I must also take my play seriously. How else would I remind myself what I am working for?
Having a captain isn't reminder enough?
Touché. But you are my capitaine in name alone, rappelles toi?
I do remember. I also remember that you've threatened to kill me more than once.
Have I? How terribly wasteful that would be!
So I did call your bluff.
Oh, I never bluff, Capitaine. I have always planned for your demise.
That's comforting.
Plan for the worst and expect the best, someone once said. Do you remember the papers I burned?
What about them?
Félicitations, Capitaine. You are free.
Were those—
The Morgana manifests. Not a shred of evidence remains connecting you to my riches.
Surcouf, I... thank you. But why?
Why what? Relinquish my leverage over you? Free you to go to Command with an incredible story of a thieving submarine?
I won't do that.
Why not?
Looks like we've both got questions. I don't want to leave them unanswered, do you? What Command doesn't know won't hurt them.
Je suis si fier de toi! I knew I'd make a criminal of you yet.
I learned it by watching you. Shall we celebrate with a Morgana flambé?
@BATTLE
There's still something bothering me.
Bien. That means you have not grown complacent!
What will you do once you're free?
Is there anything I cannot do?
Come on. You're a submarine. You can't just ask to retire.
Non. But I have many names in many ports, Capitaine. Collectors. One of them will ask la Republique if they'd be willing to part ways with me once the war is over. Once they've moved on.

Fields.MenuText: But even then, you're still stuck at sea.
Assuming you're still sailing.
I'm not so sure France will just move on from you.

Fields.DialogueText: If three-fourths of the world and all its coasts are a prison, then I go to it willingly!
Naturellement. I certainly cannot plan for after I am dead!
Tu as raison. Who in this wide world could forget me?
You've made it difficult, I'll admit.
That is a high compliment, Capitaine. I live to complicate things.
By threatening to have your acquaintances executed.
Oh, are you still on about that? A means to an end, rien de plus.
You're a liar.
I can always get a new capitaine, Capitaine. It is easy to find a weakness if you know what to look for.
Come off it. You almost killed me yourself. The last time I saw you that angry was when the Morganas attacked Cherbourg. You can't fake that kind of rage. What changed?
Do you really want to know?
It's a matter of life and death. I think I have the right.
I never keep anything I touch, Capitaine. I can resell, I can replace, I can recover. An asset is an asset.
Except when it's not.
Dear me, is that a Morgana on the horizon? Aux armes!
@BATTLE
Are you avoiding me?
Whatever gave you that idea?
I haven't seen you anywhere since we arrived at Faaa.
I may disappear when I please. I am a busy Belle, tu sais.
You never told me why you didn't have me killed.
Is it not enough to be alive? You should thank me for sparing you the brunt of my wrath!
Thank you.
... Excusez-moi?
Thank you.
Is... is that all? You don't even care?
You have your reasons. You're alive, I'm alive. We should make the most of it.
... Fine. Be that way.

Fields.MenuText: Some things you can get just by asking.
You too.
Thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: But I wasn't... it's not... tu n'es pas...
Moi? Que faites-vous...
Stop saying that!
Well, I think we're done here. Oh, and one more thing.
Et maintenant?
I know you never keep anything, but, well... I'd appreciate it if you could try just this once.
Capitaine, qu'est-ce que c'est?
My log from the first leg of the tour. It should take us right up to when you first threatened my life. Oh, the memories...
Capitaine, what are you trying to say?
Look, I'm not going to be your captain forever. You're going to be free one day.
Bien sûr.
All I ask is that you remember how you did it. You're giving the crew something to remember you by. Let me do the same for you.
Ridicule. If they all did that—
But they're not. I am.
... Capitaine, I—
Morganas on the horizon. Action stations!
@BATTLE
Oui... facteur qu'en... et...
You look busy.
Oh, Capitaine! Such a pleasant surprise! I did not expect you.
Didn't you?
Naturellement pas. It is not like you to call on me while I am working.
Hogwash. You're always working. And the empty seat across from you?
Merely for convenience.
What about the bottle of wine on your desk?
Helps me concentrate.
Surcouf, there are two glasses.
... I am a great believer in convenience.
You've also got candles lit and rose petals scattered about.
I find rose petals... convenient?

Fields.MenuText: Since when did you become such a bad liar?
If you've got something to say, say it.
I'll come back when you're a little less busy.

Fields.DialogueText: Qu'est-ce que tu racontes? Am I not making myself clear?
Capitaine, I have said all that needs to be said. Haven't I?
Wait! Capitaine, please sit down! Er... stay standing... don't go?
Whatever you've got planned, Surcouf, make it quick. The South Pacific maelstrom's getting bigger, and we're going on patrol at its edge.
What do you want from me?
You know, I've heard some frightening things about those maelstroms...
Are you listening?
Honestly, I'd be surprised if we came back in one piece.
Capitaine.
In fact, I'd really better get back to the bridge and—
Capitaine, I couldn't do it!
Do what?
I couldn't kill you! I had your life right there in my hands, a promise to take it, motif pour assassiner, and I threw it all away! Dans le feu! Rien, rien, rien...
Forgive me, Capitaine. I—
Now, what did you say about apologizing?
Capitaine, I am not myself—
Au contraire. You've never been more honest with me than at this moment.
It is unfamiliar ground, I will admit. Capitaine, you must understand, any other asset I could have disposed of, and yet...
And yet?
Vous êtes irremplaçable. I do not know why.
You don't have to.
... This does not leave my quarters.
I'd expect nothing less.
If that day ever comes when you expect less of me... scuttle me yourself.
All's fair in love and war, eh?
Come, Capitaine. A prod here, a tug there, and we shall make them unfair in our favor.
